title: Once Asking $120 Million, Stanley Druckenmiller Buys Fifth Avenue Co-op for Steep Discount
text:
A sprawling Fifth Avenue co-op that for decades was home to former Salomon Brothers chief executive John Gutfreund has sold for $53 million, a fraction of its original $120 million asking price, records show.

The buyer is billionaire trader Stanley Druckenmiller, a former investment strategist for George Soros who now invests through his own family office, according to people familiar with the deal. Mr. Druckenmiller didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.

The Former Fifth Avenue Home of the Late John Gutfreund The sprawling co-op previously owned by the former Salomon Brothers chief was recently purchased by billionaire investor Stanley Druckenmiller. An apartment that was owned by the late Wall Street executive John Gutfreund has sold for $53 million. Cary Horowitz/Brown Harris Stevens 1 of 4 • • • • • 1 of 4 Show Caption An apartment that was owned by the late Wall Street executive John Gutfreund has sold for $53 million. Cary Horowitz/Brown Harris Stevens

The roughly 12,000-square-foot duplex has more than 20 rooms, with views of Central Park. It has a dramatic entrance gallery with 24-foot ceilings, a grand marble staircase, a corner sitting room, a dining room, seven bedrooms and a 50-foot long living room with two fireplaces, according to the listing.

The property spans the seventh and eighth floors of 834 Fifth Avenue, a co-operative that was built in the early 1930s and designed by Rosario Candela. The apartment had been on the market since April 2016 and went through several price cuts. It was most recently listed for $59 million, according to StreetEasy. Mr. Gutfreund presided over Salomon during the 1991 Treasury-note auction scandal. He died in 2016. He and his wife Susan Gutfreund had owned the apartment since the 1980s, The Wall Street Journal reported when the listing came on the market. The listing agents were Serena Boardman of Sotheby’s International Realty as well as A. Laurance Kaiser IV and Craig Dix, both of Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices New York Properties, according to StreetEasy. Ms. Boardman also represented the buyer. Write to Katherine Clarke at katherine.clarke@wsj.com

description: The billionaire investor bought the roughly 12,000-square-foot duplex of the late Salomon Brothers CEO John Gutfreund for $53 million.
